bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

div1.p: The writer describes experiments involving the winter breeding of mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter to M.A. Barber, February 23, 1923
div1.p:
I have just returned from a trip in Houston and Dale Counties
and have delayed somewhat in replying to your letter.

I thank you for your offer to take care of my nephew in your
camp. I guess there is nothing doing, as you see by Frick's
letter. But I appreciate your kind offer just the same.

As to winter “quads” in the larval stage, I have not as yet b
been able to develope them.. Again last winter and this I have
been able to find Crucians and Puncts. rather plentifully, the
former in places favorable for summer quads.. However, I do have
this feeling: that on the body of ponds in flotage where winter
washings does not disturb, we have a large number passing the wins-
ter. I have just returned from Dothan, and on a pond near Newton,
development has gone on, I feel sure, all winter. In icy pond
water I made collections-- all sizes and pupae-- in large numbers
just like on these pons in the summer time. Small isolated pools
were completely covered with ice the day before. The water, there
fore was ice water, and the larvae and pupae apparently as ac-
tive as normal. This is an uncleaned pond two years old-- one of
the worst I have ever seen. Many days Dr. Carter, LeP. and I have
taken in collections smaller than this one in a summer day's work
on bad ponds.. It is my impression that bark and fine stick flo-
tage is better protection for the wintering larvae on ponds than
grasses and algae. The latter, without flotage, seems not to
hold them.

I shall be greatly interested in your quad. finding. I have
published only the one paper on wintering A. larvae, and as
you know this included only A. C. and A.B. I shall let you know
if my present collection shows quads. Anything I may have is yours
to use as you desire.
I was delighted and benefitted by Darling's recent visit.
